Introduction

The Human Tissue Act (2004) (HT Act) is the UK law which ensures human tissue is used safely and ethically, with proper consent. The HT Act covers England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It established the Human Tissue Authority (HTA) to regulate activities concerning the removal, storage, use and disposal of human tissue. Consent is the fundamental principle of the legislation. This policy outlines the background to post mortem consent and describes the process by which consent for post mortem examination is obtained and documented, and the means by which healthcare professionals seeking consent are trained to do so and demonstrated to be competent for the task.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To ensure that staff are aware of their responsibility to families of the deceased in respect of explaining and obtaining valid consent before post mortem examination;

Describe the regulatory background for the seeking of consent for the post mortem examination in the adult and paediatric setting, the latter by reference to the companion policies in place at each site 09042 Management of patients with pregnancy loss (Broomfield), CO/PR/00023 Post Mortem consent and the retention or disposal of anatomical tissues from deceased patients (Basildon) and OG 005 Maternity Bereavement Guideline (Southend)

Define who may give and who may seek consent for post mortem examination and the means by which this is documented. General principles of consent are addressed in the companion policy 04080 Consent to examination or treatment;
Describe the means by which the organisation ensures that those seeking consent for post mortem examination are trained to do so and assessed as competent to perform this task.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
MSE Pathology Board receives reporting by exception of any matters requiring escalation from MSE Pathology Governance Board.
MSE Pathology Governance Board receives annual report from HTA Governance Group.

HTA Governance Group is responsible for annual review of this policy, review of audit data on compliance with the processes it describes, and for the development of improvement actions as required. Reports by exception and annually to MSE Pathology Governance Board.
Training & Development team is responsible for administering and monitoring compliance with mandatory training for staff taking post mortem consent, reporting to HTA Governance Group.
Chief Executive as Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust.

Chief Medical Officer has executive responsibility and accountability for the implementation of this policy and associated training within the Trust. The Chief Medical Officer will usually be the representative of the HTA Corporate Licence Holder (CLH).

HTA Designated Individual (DI) authorises and supervises the licensed activity or activities, in this case the making of a post mortem examination, in accordance with the Human Tissue Act (2004) and the Codes of Practice of the Human Tissue Authority, noting that consent is the fundamental principle of the legislation. It is the responsibility of the DI to ensure processes are in place which ensure consent for post mortem examination is obtained in accordance with this policy and the HTA Codes of Practice.

Persons Designated: A Person Designated by the DI acts at a local (eg departmental or other area of practice) level to assist the DI in ensuring licensed activities are undertaken in accordance with the relevant standards and codes of practice of the HT Act, to promptly alert the DI to any emerging risks, HTA Reportable Incidents (HTARI) or HTARI near-misses in their area of practice and to promote and advocate for the safe and ethical use of human tissue, with proper consent, in their area of practice.

Clinical Directors and Service Leads – responsible for ensuring that newly appointed clinicians in the service areas who will be required to seek post mortem consent are directed to read this policy and to enrol in the associated mandatory training.

Clinicians seeking consent - It is the responsibility of staff seeking consent for post mortem examination to ensure that valid consent has been obtained from the patient before such an examination takes place, which includes any removal of Relevant Material (human tissue, see section 5.1, below) from the body of a deceased person. Before seeking consent, clinicians must ensure they have been trained in post mortem consent in accordance with the training framework set out in this policy (see section 6, below) and have demonstrated ongoing competence in this procedure.

Pathologists undertaking post mortem examinations by consent (“Hospital post mortems”) – the pathologist must carefully review the completed consent form before commencing any part of the post mortem procedure. They must satisfy themselves that consent is clearly and unequivocally documented and must raise any queries with the consent taker, mindful that ambiguous or contradictory consent is invalid. If any doubt exists as to the wishes of the deceased and/or the person in a qualifying relationship who gave consent on their behalf, or if there is any doubt as to the appropriateness of the person giving or taking consent, pause must be taken to explore and resolve the matter of concern before proceeding.
The Head of Midwifery is responsible for ensuring Midwives follow consent procedures for post mortem for babies.
Background

The Human Tissue Act (2004) (HT Act) is the UK law which ensures human tissue is used safely and ethically, with proper consent. The HT Act covers England, Wales and Northern Ireland. It established the Human Tissue Authority (HTA) to regulate activities concerning the removal, storage, use and disposal of human tissue. Consent is the fundamental principle of the legislation. Different consent requirements apply when dealing with tissue from the deceased and the living.

The HTA regulate a number of different sectors, the settings in which human tissue may be used. These are anatomy, bone marrow & peripheral blood & stem cell donation, organ donation, public display, research and the post mortem. This policy focuses on the post mortem.

The HT Act applies to what it defines as “Relevant Material”. This is any material that is made from or contains human cells (other than gametes) - in simple terms, organs, tissues and cells. The HT Act lists the purposes for which consent is required (these are called Scheduled Purposes) in order to make use of relevant materials.
Purposes requiring consent whether from a living or deceased person.
Consent for the following purposes is always required whether the person is alive or dead at the time the material is collected or removed.
Anatomical examination;
Determining the cause of death;
Establishing after a person's death the efficacy of any drug or other treatment administered to them; obtaining scientific or medical information about a living or deceased person;
Public display;
Research in connection with disorders, or the functioning, of the human body;
Transplantation.

In the case of public display and anatomical examination, removal cannot take place based on someone else's consent; if consent was not obtained from the individual before they died, the tissue or organ(s) cannot be taken. For all other cases listed above, consent can be obtained from someone else (see the “qualifying relationships” below).
Purposes requiring consent for tissue or organs taken from the deceased but not if taken from the living.

In order to carry out any of the activities listed below with tissue collected or removed from the deceased, appropriate consent must have been given. However, additional consent is not needed to carry out these activities using tissue taken from a living person, who will already have consented for the procedure they are undergoing
Clinical audit;
Education or training relating to human health;
Performance assessment;
Public health monitoring
Quality assurance.

The HT Act does not apply to post mortem examinations undertaken by order of the coroner and therefore these do not require consent and can be undertaken against the wishes of the family. As soon as a coroner concludes their investigation and their interest in the deceased ends, the coronial exemption cease and the HT Act applies to any retained relevant materials. Unless consent has been sought in advance, or is sought at that point, any remaining materials must then be lawfully and respectfully disposed of within a permitted period of 3 months.

The majority of post mortem examinations in the UK are undertaken by order of a coroner, but if a death does not require coronial investigation, a post mortem examination can still been requested by either the clinician or a relative. Under these circumstances the HT Act applies because such an examination would constitute a scheduled purpose, and consent from a person in a qualifying relationship to the deceased is required. The details of this process are outlined in this document.
Why a hospital post mortem examination may be required
A hospital post mortem may be requested to:
Confirm the nature of the illness and/or extent of the disease
Identify other conditions that may not have been diagnosed
Assess the effects of treatments and drugs and identify any complications or side-effects.
For purposes of education and governance.
To assist the family in further understanding the cause of death and any implications it may have for them.
In the case of a baby or child (up to the age of  years)
Help plan future pregnancies and care in pregnancies
Diagnose and treat conditions in other children in the family
Who should seek consent?

HTA guidance states that it is the treating clinician's responsibility to seek consent from a person in a qualifying relationship. The clinician may delegate this task to a person who has been specifically trained to take hospital post mortem consent.

This person should be suitably senior and have good medical knowledge. They should have been trained in the purpose and procedures of a post mortem and they should have witnessed a post mortem examination.
The HTA Designated Individual for each site and the Mortuary Managers are available to provide guidance on taking post mortem consent and the HT Act, as required.

To comply with the HT Act, documented evidence of consent training must be available for the person taking consent, along with documented evidence of update training (CPD, refresher training, witnessing a post mortem.) A record of clinicians who have attended the Trust's consent training is maintained by the MSE Training & Development team on behalf of the HTA Designated Individual for each MSE site.

Prior to meeting with the relatives to take consent, the consent taker should contact the mortuary for advice on which pathologist will perform the post mortem examination and when it will be undertaken. The consent taker should then meet or discuss the case with the pathologist who will undertake the post mortem examination, to discuss whether a full or limited post mortem is required, along with

any other specific tests which may be required, which may require specific consent to be obtained. This may include the retention of fluid, small tissue samples (“tissue blocks”) or whole organs, subject to the matters under investigation and entirely conditional upon the wishes of the person in a qualifying relationship (see section 5.4, below) giving consent.

It is important that this discussion takes place so that the consent taker can accurately communicate the degree to which any limitation or restriction the family may choose is likely to impact upon the information likely to be yielded by the post mortem examination. This is fundamental to their informed consent.
Who can give consent? The qualifying relationships

If the deceased person has not indicated their consent (or refusal) to post-mortem removal, storage or use of their body or tissue for scheduled purposes, or appointed a nominated representative, then the appropriate consent may be given by someone who was in a ‘qualifying relationship' with the deceased person immediately before their death. Those in a qualifying relationship are found in the HT Act in the following order (highest first).

An adult may appoint one or more nominated representatives to carry out their wishes after death in relation to activities for which consent under the HT Act is required. An executor is not automatically classified as a nominated representative and would need to be specifically appointed to this role in line with the requirements of the HT Act.

Consent is needed from only one person in the hierarchy of qualifying relationships and should be obtained from the person ranked highest. If a person higher up the list refuses to give consent, it is not possible to act on consent from someone further down the list. For example, if a spouse refuses but other relatives wish to give consent, the wishes of the spouse must be respected. However, the guidance below should be observed in line with this principle. If there is no one available in a qualifying relationship to make a decision on consent (and consent had not been indicated by the deceased person or a nominated representative), it is not lawful to proceed with removal, storage or use of the deceased person's body, organs or tissue for scheduled purposes.

While the HT Act is clear about the hierarchy of consent, the person giving consent should be encouraged to discuss the decision with other relatives. This may include people not on the list, for example, an aunt or uncle.

Relationships listed together, for example ‘brother or sister', are accorded equal ranking, in which case it is sufficient to obtain consent from just one of them, provided they are ranked equal highest. For example, if the deceased person has no spouse or partner, but has several children, the consent of only one child is required.

Where there is a conflict between those accorded equal ranking, this should be discussed sensitively with all parties, whilst explaining clearly that so far as the HT Act is concerned, the consent of one of those ranked equally in the hierarchy is sufficient for the procedure to go ahead. This does not mean that the consent of one person must be acted on, and a decision not to proceed may be made on the basis of the emotional impact that this would have on family and friends.

If those close to the deceased person object to the procedure, for whatever purpose, when the deceased person (or their nominated representative) has explicitly consented, the healthcare professional should seek to discuss the matter sensitively with them. They should be encouraged to accept the deceased person's wishes and it should be made clear that they do not have the legal right to revoke valid consent.
The emphasis in these difficult situations should be placed on having an open and sensitive discussion with those close to the deceased where the process is explained fully to them.

A person may be omitted from the hierarchy if they cannot be located in reasonable time for the activity in question to be addressed, decline to deal with the matter or are unable to do so, for example, because they are a child or lack capacity to consent. In such cases, the next person in the hierarchy would become the appropriate person to give consent.

Consent is only valid if proper communication has taken place. Particular consideration should be given to the needs of individuals and families whose first language is not English. Any difficulties in communicating, for example, because of language, literacy or hearing difficulties, should be recorded along with an explanation of how these difficulties were overcome.

Consent must be given before the post-mortem examination is undertaken to ensure proper compliance with the HT Act. Therefore, before the post-mortem examination begins, the pathologist must check that it has been properly consented to, either by the deceased person before they died, or their nominated representative, or their relatives.

A suitable private room away from the clinical area should be used. If a face-to-face meeting is not possible because relatives are unable attend in person, consent to a post mortem examination may be given orally, and if possible this conversation should be recorded and then the relative must be provided with a letter of confirmation together with a copy of the consent form and any other relevant documentation.
Information leaflets providing support and information for the bereaved are available from the Bereavement Offices and Mortuaries at each MSE site.
Documentation of consent: the consent form
Hospital post mortem examination of an adult:

Consent should be taken using “Post-Mortem Examination of an Adult Consent Form” (Appendix A). This includes both the consent form itself and a section for the requesting clinician to document the background clinical history and questions for the pathologist, which together form the request to perform a post mortem examination.
Hospital post mortem examination of a baby or child:

All bereaved parents should be offered a post mortem examination. There is no right or wrong time to discuss the post-mortem examination and this is understandably a difficult and emotive subject to broach. An appropriate discussion is however a very important part of care and the timing of the discussion will vary from case to case, but can begin before the baby is born. For some families there may be cultural or religious implications regarding post mortem examination, and it is important to be aware of these, however it is equally as important not to make the assumption that certain cultural groups will automatically decline post mortem and not offer the parents full discussion of this option.

All paediatric post mortem examinations take place at either Addenbrookes Hospital (Broomfield) or Great Ormond Street Hospital (Southend & Basildon) by direct referral from the Maternity Unit. The companion policies 09042 Management of patients with pregnancy loss  (Broomfield site),  OG  Maternity Bereavement Guideline (Southend) and CO/PR/00023 Post Mortem consent and the retention or disposal of anatomical tissues from deceased patients (Basildon) describe in detail the management of pregnancy loss including bereavement support, requesting a post mortem examination, the taking of consent and logistical arrangements for transfer to the specialist hospital. Consent should be taken using “Post-Mortem Examination of a Baby or Child” form (Appendix B) in accordance with the principles set out in this policy and the process set out in 09042 Management of patients with pregnancy loss and OG 005 Maternity Bereavement Guideline, OG  Maternity Bereavement Guideline and CO/PR/00023 Post Mortem consent and the retention or disposal of anatomical tissues from deceased patients as applicable to the site at which the death has occurred. All supporting documentation is available from the respective site Maternity Units.
Withdrawal of consent

The person in a qualifying relationship who has given consent may change their mind about any of the decisions they make, within a period of up to 24hrs. To make any changes to anything they have consented too, or to withdraw their consent completely, they should telephone the Bereavement Office or Mortuary as soon as possible.
Broomfield: Bereavement Office 9-4pm Mon-Friday (01245 514020) or Mortuary (01245
Basildon: Bereavement Office 10-4pm Mon-Friday (01268 394850).
Southend: Bereavement Office 10 - 5pm Mon to Thursday and 10 - 4.30pm Friday (01702
Training requirements

HTA guidance states that it is the treating clinician's responsibility to seek consent. The clinician may delegate this task to a person who has been specifically trained to take hospital post mortem consent. This person should be suitably senior and have good medical knowledge. They should have been trained in the purpose and procedures of a post mortem and they should have witnessed a post mortem examination.

MSE provides a training package consisting of an online component which is reinforced by an interactive face to face session delivered twice a year by one of the MSE DIs. New consent takers must complete the electronic package and then attend the next available face to face session.

Thereafter, the online component must be reviewed once every two years. It is not necessary to repeat the face to face session, however it is emphasised that advice and support is available at any time from pathologists, the site DI's and Mortuary Managers.

After reading this policy, witnessing a post mortem examination and completing both components of the training package, participants will be equipped with the knowledge required to seek and document valid post mortem consent compliant with the HTA Codes of Practice. That this has been achieved will be recorded as part of the individual clinician's training and development portfolio.

The Training and Development team is responsible for administration of the training package and for maintaining records of completion by eligible clinicians. This forms part of the Trust's mandatory training assurance framework. Compliance data are reported to the HTA Governance Group.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the MSE Pathology Board prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Pathology Board and key staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment

The policy provides guidance on the process of post mortem consent and the legal framework behind it and is therefore by definition, by consent. The process and legal framework of consent applies equally to all.

This policy embraces diversity, dignity and inclusion in line with emerging human rights' guidance. We recognise, acknowledge and value difference across all people and their backgrounds. We will treat everyone with courtesy and consideration and ensure that no one is belittled, excluded or disadvantaged in anyway.
(Refer to appendix 3)

Introduction

“The HT Act defines ‘appropriate consent' by reference to the person who may give consent. This is broadly either the person concerned, their nominated representative or in the absence of either of these, a person in a ‘qualifying relationship' with them immediately before they died. An adult may appoint one or more nominated representatives to carry out their wishes after death in relation to activities for which consent under the HT Act is required. An executor is not automatically classified as a nominated representative and would need to be specifically appointed to this role in line with the requirements of the HT Act”. See Guidance note 3 for more information.

The consent form is important as a record of consent given. The completion of the form is just one part of the consent process. Full explanation of the PM examination procedure along with discussion and time for reflection by those consenting, are equally important. Individuals and relatives should be able to discuss this process fully and ask any questions. Staff seeking consent for PM examination must be trained in how to obtain valid consent.
Consent is only valid if proper communication has taken place. Consideration should be given to the needs of individuals and families whose first language is not English.
The consent form covers consent for the PM examination itself as well as for the retention and use of organs and tissue following the PM examination.”
This form is not to be used for seeking consent of a post mortem on stillbirths, neonatal deaths, foetal tissue or non-foetal products of conception.

The storage of the tissue samples and their later use require your consent. These samples can be valuable for the education and training of healthcare professionals, research and other purposes.
